oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Silver Dollar Saloon
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Detailed view of the exterior door to Silver Dollar Saloon in V.E. Schwab Building at Broadway and Second Avenue. The entrance is canted to the street corner. The door has elaborate trim and molding. Terra cotta embellishments appear on the façade above the door. The door has a panel of patterned glass. Striped awnings hang above the storefront windows.

The Silver Dollar Saloon, located at 100 Market Street (Second Avenue), is a three-story Romanesque brick building designed by architect Julius G. Zwicker and completed in 1893. In 1889, V. E. Schwab purchased the property at Broad and Market Street. The building has terra cotta details, including a wreath and shells on the façade. A turret is above the main entrance to the building. Other architectural details include a large cornice with a terracotta frieze, stringcourse molding, and large encased arched windows on the second floor. The building's name came from the floors made of silver dollars. V. E. Schwab was associated with George A. Dickel & Co., as his brother-in-law was George A. Dickel, and the saloon served their whiskey. The saloon attracted riverboat crews who worked nearby, with it offering drinks, lunch, and lodging. During prohibition, the saloon transformed into a soft drink emporium and restaurant.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Boucher, Jack E.; Historic American Buildings Survey
